headline: World Us Announces New Sanctions Russia Billions More Aid Ukraine
summary: On thefirst anniversary of Russia's "special military operation" in Ukraine, the U.S. announced new sanctions on Russia and $12 billion in new aid for Ukraine.The Aid:The U.S. will send Ukraine $2 billion in additional military equipment, including 155 mm artillery ammunition, rocket system munitions, mine detection equipment, and more. Secretary of State Antony Blinken also announced an additional $10 billion aid package, which includes roughly $250 million to address “immediate" power grid needs. Blinken said the funds "will help keep schools open, power generators for hospitals running, and keep homes and shelters across Ukraine warm."The Sanctions:The sanctions target dozens of financial institutions, companies, and entities in Russia’s metals and mining sector, as well as international firms suspected of helping Moscow try to evade previous sanctions. The moves block the companies’ assets in the U.S. and restrict American citizens from doing business with them.For Context:Acongressional reportfrom December 2022 said sanctions have cost Russia hundreds of billions of dollars and decreased its military efficiency. The U.S. has now committednearly $90 billion in financial assistance to Ukrainesince January 2022.How the Media Covered It:The aid was a top story across the spectrum Friday, especially from left- and center-rated sources. Outlets on both left and right, includingCBS News (Lean Left bias)andDaily Caller (Right bias), highlighted concerns that the U.S.may experiencea weapons shortageif Ukraine aid continues at its current pace.
